bibl.title: Letter from [Ralph Cooper Hutchison] to Philip Showalter Hench, September 7, 1940

div1.p: [Hutchison] gives Hench details on the upcoming exercises honoring Lazear at Washington and Jefferson College.

div1.head: Letter from [Ralph Cooper Hutchison] to Philip Showalter Hench, September 7, 1940

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
September 7, 1940

div1.p:
I am just back from our vacation and in the
grand pile-up which we always have at this time of
year, but I am anxious to get some word to you. I find
two of your letters here and I particularly want to thank
you for the gift of two hundred dollars to take care
of the expenses of Mr. Moran, or to use otherwise as
necessary. I tried to get a date with Mr. Pew for
Saturday when I will be in Philadelphia, but he could not
see me and I've got to try and get him some time a week
later and will do so. If he should be willing to pay
the expenses of Moran, what would you think of our using
the money which you sent, or rather a portion of it, for
the expenses of Kissinger? I will discuss with you
later the use of the balance. For the moment I want to
express our very deep and sincere gratitude for this gift.
It helps us out tremendously. We had hard luck last year
and went about five thousand in the hole and will have a
very stringent budget this year. Therefore gifts at this
time for such expenses mean a tremendous amount to us
and to me personally as you can know. My deepest thanks
to you.

Miss Hough has been working on the pictures
which you requested and has them ready and we are sending
them along now.

You will recall my writing to you about this
Doctor Barker of Baltimore who knew a good deal about
Lazear. I wrote him a letter and I think I sent you a
carbon. I have received a letter from him containing
quantities of information and I have had a copy made for
you which I enclose herewith.

I take it that you are straightened out in
regard to Doctor Lazear's course here. It was a curious
thing that he took a Bachelor's Degree at Hopkins after
leaving here and I do not know why that was done or how
it happened. It is a point, however, which has no
particular bearing and I wouldn't bother with it when you
are here unless it appeals to you for some reason. There
was no question about his doing his college work here.
Apparently he was born in Baltimore and his family was
from there and somehow they got into the Pittsburgh area
before he went to college. We ran onto a paragraph
concerning him this summer in a book about old Baltimore.
Doctor Philip S. Hench
-2-
September 6, 1940
The paragraph is somewhat inaccurate but it gives a little
more light upon him. I will send you a copy of that.

There are a number of details to take up with
you later as I get to them, but for the moment I think
of one more thing on which you might be working. In as much
as you are receiving an honorary degree at the exercises
on Friday morning, October the twenty-sixth, we would
like very much to send formal invitations to those exercises
to a list of your friends and relatives. The regular
invitation will go to them and in it will be a slip saying
that they are receiving the invitation because you are
receiving an honorary degree. Work up your list and send
it in as soon as convenient.

Naturally, Mr. Moran has not answered the letter
which I gave to you to carry to him. Should I not write
him again now and repeat the invitation officially for him
to come here? The question of what recognition or honor
we can give to these men if they come has not been cleared,
even in my own mind, but I think we will make it very nice
for them no matter how it is done.

Hope everything is well at your house. Please
give my love to Mary and to the children, and we are looking
forward to Founders' Day which will be memorable for me
because of you.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
